titleStmt.title: Despatch from Samuel S. Sevier to George L. Rives, June 26, 1888

bibl.title: Despatch from Samuel S. Sevier to George L. Rives, June 26, 1888
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p: Hon G. L. Rives Assistant Secretary of State Washington D. C.

Sir: Your letter of May 26th 1888, came to hand when I was from; therefore I could not reply. I now take this opportunity to say that it is impossible for me to send in, to the State Department proper voucher for messenger service rendered the U.S. Legation at Monrovia Liberia for the amount of $75 50/100 because I cannot get said proper voucher from the messenger, for I don't know where he is. And
again, Sir, if I could get a voucher it would not be a proper one; because the messenger cannot write his name. He was a native man of the land one who could hardly speak the English language.

Sir, please deal with me kindly and let me have my money ($75 50/100) for I am in need of it. I am willing to take oath on the fate of my life that I paid the messenger of the U.S. Legation at Monrovia Liberiea that money. Please give me justice. I know you will do what is right and just. Hoping to hear from you soon.
I remain, Sir, Yours with Highest esteem
